published_attributes.title: Productivity 101 - TOC
published_attributes.serialized_body:
In this short introductory course we will walk you through some basic tools and concepts in the wide topic of productivity, which include: prioritizing, delegating, scheduling, focusing.

  1. Introduction
  2. Time Management, Attention and Energy
  3. Bird-eye view - Pareto
  4. Prioritizing & Delegating - Eisenhower Matrix
  5. Prioritizing - MoSCoW
  6. Productivity Curve & Attention Curve
  7. Focus - Pomodoro
  8. Focus - Deliberate practice

published_attributes.title: Some people are productive
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Introduction

When trying to compile my masters thesis many, many years ago, and struggling to meet the deadlines, I was told by my scholarly supervisor that "some people are productive." When I think about it now, he obviously did not have me in mind back then.

It, however, made me think 🤔:

Is productivity a matter of personality or is it more hard work on getting your s**t together and maintaining a certain level of self-discipline?

I’d like to believe it’s the latter, so let's break it down into some edible bites.

In this very brief course you will learn about some basic methods that will help you support productivity. Productivity is a choice and an action plan. There are a lot of things you can do to make the best use of your time, focus, attention, and energy levels. You might not have control over how tired you are, but you can learn to work with the varying levels and make it work to your advantage.

published_attributes.title: Time Management, Attention and Energy
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Contrary to some popular nomenclature, managing time is not possible (unless you have superpowers🧞‍♀️). Time flow is outside of our control, therefore there is no way to actually influence it.

Sometimes we might also come across the term "managing self in time," but this actually is quite misleading and not specific enough.

💡 What we can and should manage is our mental production. Thus, what we can do though, is to use productivity techniques to manage our attention, focus and deliberation. 

ATTENTION & FOCUS MANAGEMENT:

Attention is like a stream. It flows where ever it wants, slightly restrained by the terrain. Focus, on the other hand, is the harnessed stream, flowing strong but managed. Never thought of it this way before? Well, now you will. You're welcome.

Here's an article by Adam Grant that nails the point 👇.

And even more, this article by Maura Thomas, an HBR author, points to a few crucial aspects of attention management, too.

ENERGY MANAGEMENT:

Energy is a scare resource, not only in the global scope, but also quite locally. We have a limited amount of energy to spare every day and our job is to manage the distribution wisely, which we often fail.

Attention and focus rely directly on and come from the source of energy. Energy depletion will immediately translate into attention deficit, lack of focus and poor "time management".

Thus, start with your daily energy allocation, monitor it throughout the day and adjust accordingly. It's ok to be drained and not function at your best. But it's even more than OK to know when your energy declines and to adjust your activities to that.

[More on that coming in the later parts of the course.]

published_attributes.title: Bird-eye view - Pareto Principle
published_attributes.serialized_body:
The Pareto Principle says that that for many results, roughly 80% of consequences come from 20% of causes.

💡 This means that as much as 80% of our time is devoted to activities which, in the long run, yield only 20% of valuable outcomes.

Having this in mind think about where you allocate your time. You may want to sketch out your actions and their consequences. Try estimating where the real impact is and what are just reactive actions.

published_attributes.title: Prioritizing & Delegating - the Eisenhower Matrix
published_attributes.serialized_body:
The Eisenhower Matrix is a useful tool that will help you organize your tasks, prioritize and delegate them.

Our actions can be divided into 4 categories based on their importance or impact and the urgency.

As a result, you may decide to choose one of the following:

  • Do It
  • Schedule It
  • Delegate It
  • Delete It

*source - Canva

published_attributes.title: Prioritizing - MoSCoW
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Another tool that might help you. deal with priorities is the MoSCoW model which stands for :

Must have
Should have
Could have
Will NOT have

Similarly to the Eisenhower Martix, MoSCoW helps to organize the priorities. It however, focuses more on the importance of the activities, rather than their time definition and urgency.

published_attributes.title: Task 2.
published_attributes.serialized_body:
TASK:

Make a list of the things of your emerging projects and tasks. Evaluate them according to the Eisenhower Matrix or the MoSCoW model.

What can you cross off of your to-do list?

Do you have any refections on your priorities? Share them with others, please in the comments.

published_attributes.title: Productivity Curve & Attention Curve
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Once you get the priorities straight, the key thing is to understand your own Productivity & Attention Curves. 

Productivity Curve

There are normally 2 peaks in your daily productivity, separated by a productivity decline. Please mind you, the ascribed hours are just a reference, your exact times might differ.

The 1st peak should be reserved for priorities, the 2nd for other important issues. The decline is great for mundane routines.

Attention Curve

The Attention Curve is similar for any activities you take upon and is divided into 3 phases:

published_attributes.title: Focus - Pomodoro
published_attributes.serialized_body:
The Pomodoro Technique is a focus management method developed by Francesco Cirillo in the late 1980s. It uses a timer to break work into shorter intervals of focused practice, typically of 25 minutes. After each interval there should be a break of approximately 5 minutes and relaxation or treat.

Each interval is known as a pomodoro, from the Italian word for tomato, after the tomato-shaped kitchen timer.

This is a simple, yet powerful technique that will help you stay focused and continue working.

A good and simple tool to help you with that is this browser-based timer - Pomofocus. Go ahead and try it out.

published_attributes.title: Focus - Deliberate practice
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Deliberate practice is something we tend to forget about these days. We are lured by the promise of great, quick effect with little effort devoted. This is a myth, unfortunately.

Getting any real result with learning or work required effort, attention, devotion and time. Deliberate practice is here to help.

"Deliberate practice is the best technique for achieving expert performance in every field—including writing, teaching, sports, programming, music, medicine, therapy, chess, and business. But there’s much more to deliberate practice than 10,000 hours. [...]

As a general concept, “practice” means preparing. It’s the act of repeatedly performing certain activities with the intention of improving a specific associated skill. We rehearse what to do in low-pressure situations so we’ll be better when we use a skill in situations where something is actually at stake, such as in a competition or in the workplace." (source)

And if you want to learn more about deliberate practice, you MUST read James Clear's articles on it. Seriously, James is the best.writer.ever.

published_attributes.title: Over to you
published_attributes.serialized_body:
You have had a chance to take a look at various tools that can help you manage your focus and attention, which are crucial for productivity.

The ball is now in your court - try implementing the tools and see which works best for you.

If there are any thoughts you'd like to share with others, please feel fre to do so in the comments below 👇.

Thank you for your attention 😉.

Please remember to click "complete".
